page.title: 08St.John's Piddinghoe
page.content: St.John's church stands overlooking the river Ouse. The church is of medium construction and faced with flint. It has an unusual tower (there are only two other examples of round towers to be seen in Sussex). The round tower is topped with an octagonal wooden shingle steeple, which was renewed in 1980 using Canadian Cedar. There is a weather vane of a large gilded fish (mentioned by Kipling in one of his poems). The present building, origionally of the 12th century has a nave with rounded Norman arches, flanked on either side by side aisles rebuilt during the restoration of 1882. The font and the chancel both date from the 13th century. The stained glass (with the exception in 1983 of an example by Marguerite Douglas-Thompson) dates from the restoration in 1882
